security: The Morgan file includes information from 1959-1974, some of which describes potential issues with his character, such as a cable stating that "it would be a serious mistake for any u.s. gout agency to...recruit morgan for operational purpose. morgan Who reportedly under local cloud is perectly capable betraying u.s. or his own mother if it would advance his personal interests."
summary: This document includes a transmittal form for documents forwarded from the CIA's Office of Legislative Counsel to Mr. Robert Morrison of the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) concerning sanitized notes on individuals, including William Alexander Morgan and George de Mohrenschildt, plus notes on a Deryabin file and David Ferrie; the document then transitions into sanitized notes regarding William Alexander Morgan with information spanning 1959-1974, discussing potential recruitment by the U.S. Army and CIA objections.
summary_one_paragraph: On June 5, 1978, the CIA's Office of Legislative Counsel sent documents to Robert Morrison of the HSCA, including sanitized notes on Leslie Wiselman's interviews related to William Alexander Morgan and George de Mohrenschildt, Bob Genxman's notes on Daniel A. Parsons, and Jim Wolf's notes on the Deryabin file and Patricia Orr's notes on David W. Ferrie; also included are sanitized notes on Herman Greenspun and Gordon McLendon; the file relating to William Alexander Morgan contains information from 1959-1974, which includes discussion regarding the U.S. Army's interest in recruiting him, the CIA's objections to his recruitment due to concerns about his character and loyalty, and details of his activities in Cuba, plus information on Frank Emmick and Gus Kangos.
title: Human Capital and Document Receipt
